summary: This document is a compilation of news articles from July 15, 2019, summarizing key revelations from Jeffrey Epstein's bail hearing in the Southern District of New York. It details prosecutors' arguments against bail, including the discovery of cash, diamonds, and a fake passport in Epstein's safe, testimony from alleged victims, and discussions of his finances and potential witness tampering.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central defendant in the sex trafficking case, arrested on July 6, 2019. Prosecutors argued he is a flight risk and danger to the community, opposing his bail request.

persons.name: Richard Berman
persons.context: Presided over Epstein's bail hearing, delayed his decision until July 18, 2019, and expressed skepticism about Epstein's financial disclosure and bail proposal.

persons.name: Martin Weinberg
persons.context: Argued for Epstein's release on bail, claiming Epstein had engaged in '14 years of self-discipline' and that payments to associates were not witness tampering.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.role: Former U.S. Attorney / Former Labor Secretary
persons.context: The former U.S. Attorney in Miami who brokered Epstein's controversial 2008 non-prosecution agreement. He resigned as Labor Secretary on July 12, 2019, amid public outrage.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Represented three women who accused Epstein of abuse. He argued to the court that Epstein's payments after a Miami Herald article caused witnesses to stop cooperating.

persons.name: Les Wexner
persons.context: Identified in the document as the only known billionaire client of Epstein's investment firm, Financial Trust Company.

persons.name: Adam Raymond
persons.context: Author of one of the summarized news articles about the bail hearing.

persons.name: Tom Winter
persons.context: Co-author of one of the summarized news articles about the bail hearing.

persons.name: David Li
persons.context: Co-author of one of the summarized news articles about the bail hearing.

persons.name: Benjamin Weiser
persons.context: Co-author of one of the summarized news articles about the bail hearing.

persons.name: Ali Watkins
persons.context: Co-author of one of the summarized news articles about the bail hearing.

persons.name: Bob Van Voris
persons.context: Co-author of one of the summarized news articles about the bail hearing.

persons.name: Chris Dolmetsch
persons.context: Co-author of one of the summarized news articles about the bail hearing.

persons.name: Patricia Hurtado
persons.context: Co-author of one of the summarized news articles about the bail hearing.

persons.name: Peter Whoriskey
persons.context: Co-author of an article analyzing the potential impact of legal proceedings on Epstein's fortune.

persons.name: Abha Bhattarai
persons.context: Co-author of an article analyzing the potential impact of legal proceedings on Epstein's fortune.

persons.name: Paul Cassell
persons.context: Quoted as a lawyer for an alleged victim, estimating Epstein's potential financial exposure could exceed $500 million in federal court and $1 billion in state court.

persons.name: Hector Balderas
persons.context: Reported to be investigating whether Epstein committed crimes in New Mexico, where he owned the Zorro Ranch.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Mentioned as having been part of Epstein's legal team.

persons.name: Kenneth W. Starr
persons.context: Mentioned as having been part of Epstein's legal team.

persons.name: Thomas Volscho
persons.context: Researcher who expressed doubt that Epstein was a billionaire, estimating his wealth at possibly above $200 million.

connections.description: Weinberg is identified as Epstein's defense attorney, arguing for his bail and defending him in court.
Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, brokered the 2008 non-prosecution agreement that allowed Epstein to avoid federal indictment.
Wexner is identified as the only known billionaire client of Epstein's investment firm.
Adversarial relationship; Boies is an attorney representing alleged victims of Epstein in civil suits.
Dershowitz is mentioned as having been part of Epstein's legal team.
Starr is mentioned as having been part of Epstein's legal team.

events.title: Epstein Bail Hearing
events.description: A federal bail hearing for Jeffrey Epstein where prosecutors argued against release, revealing discovery of cash, diamonds, and a fake passport in his safe, and where two alleged victims testified.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey after arriving on his private jet from Paris, on charges of sex trafficking and conspiracy.

events.title: Florida Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Epstein signed a controversial deal with federal prosecutors in Florida, pleading guilty to state charges and serving 13 months in jail, thereby avoiding a federal indictment.

events.title: Acosta Resignation
events.description: Labor Secretary Alex Acosta resigned following public outrage over his role in approving Epstein's 2008 non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: Scheduled Bail Decision
events.description: Judge Richard Berman scheduled to deliver his decision on whether to grant Epstein bail.

events.title: Epstein's Payments After Miami Herald Story
events.description: Two days after the Miami Herald published an investigative series on Epstein, he wired $350,000 to two potential witnesses. Prosecutors alleged this was witness tampering.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York City
Epstein's Upper East Side Mansion, Manhattan, New York
St. Thomas, Virgin Islands (address of Financial Trust Company)
Saudi Arabia (listed as residence on fake passport)
keyFacts: During a search of Epstein's Manhattan mansion, the FBI found a safe containing piles of cash, diamonds, and an expired foreign passport with Epstein's photo but a different name, listing his residence as Saudi Arabia.

Two women who alleged Epstein abused them when they were 14 and 16 years old testified at the bail hearing, urging the judge to deny bail, with one stating, 'He's a scary person to have walking the street.'

Prosecutors revealed evidence suggesting Epstein is worth at least $500 million, with one bank account containing $110 million, and accused him of wiring $350,000 to potential witnesses after a damaging news article was published.
Judge Richard Berman expressed dissatisfaction with Epstein's 'cursory' and 'unverified' financial disclosure and delayed his bail decision until July 18, 2019.
The document notes that Epstein's 2008 non-prosecution agreement was approved by several high-level DOJ officials beyond Alex Acosta, some of whom later held positions in the Trump administration.
